metadata.title: Clubfoot
anatomical location body part affected: Foot/bone, muscle and tendon of the forefoot, midfoot, heel and ankle
description: Congenital talipes equinovarus (clubfoot) is a three-dimensional complex musculoskeletal malformation of the lower extremity and foot characterized by four components: ankle equinus, heel varus, midfootcavus, and metatarsus adductus. It is usually a combination of bony deformity and soft tissue contracture(11)
Clubfoot in the United States and Great Britain has an incidence of 1 to 2 per 1,000 live births (0.1 to 0.2%); it is 2 times more common in males. Clubfoot is bilateral in 50% of cases(11)
This Clinical Review focuses on research evaluating nonsurgical management of clubfoot in babies

ICD-10 codes.Q66.0: talipesequinovarus (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no special agencies or specific issues regarding reimbursement for therapy have been identified for clubfoot
presentation signs and symptoms: Unilateral or bilateral clubfoot features: ankle equinus, heel varus, midfootcavus, and metatarsus adductus(11)
Painless until pressure sores develop secondary to weight-bearing  on the untreated clubfoot
Additional signs/symptoms may develop if walking begins before the deformity is corrected (see Pathogenesis , below) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Notify physician immediately if no sensation or motor response is found in the affected foot
Postpone examination of patients with unresolved conditions such as foot infection, unhealed surgical wound, or fracture
Follow physician/surgeon’s orders and postoperative protocol as closely as possible. Noncompliance with bracing in the Ponseti method is associated with relapse(11)

causes: Clubfoot is considered idiopathic except in cases in which it is part of a musculoskeletalor neurological syndrome (e.g., muscular dystrophy, cerebral palsy, meningomyelocele,or arthrogryposis) present at birth(11)
Insufficient medial rotation (pronation) of the foot in utero may contribute

Authors of a 2018 systematic review of the etiology of idiopathic clubfoot suggest thatseveral genetic pathways are associated with abnormal limb and muscle contractileprotein development, but no major candidate gene has been identified. The environmenthas also been implicated in the disease pathogenesis. A clear cause of clubfoot has notbeen determined(22)
pathogenesis: Cases vary from mild (soft foot) to severe (rigid foot), or 0 to 20 on the Dimeglio classification system(1)–After applying a gentle corrective maneuver to the foot, the residual deformity is assessed using the Dimeglioclassification (a 20-point  scoring system). Based on the score, a grade of 1-IV  is assigned to the deformity

Contractures are widespread and conform to the bony deformities–Achilles tendon is almost always involved–Tibialis posterior muscle/posterior tibial tendon–Long and intrinsic toe flexors–Abductor hallucis muscle–Plantar aponeurosis

In cases of a neglected clubfoot, the following conditions can arise, impacting the child’s overall quality of life(10)–Skin ulceration and possible infection–Weight-bearing  on dorsolateral side of foot–Progressive atrophy of involved calf muscles–Growth retardation of affected foot and leg
risk factors: Two times more common in males than females(11)
Smoking or exposure to solvents in the 3 months before pregnancy or during the first trimester(15)–Based on a study of 121 cases of clubfoot from the Norwegian Medical Birth Registry

overall contraindications precautions: Treating clinicians should have appropriate training for this diagnosis
Obtain written referral from attending pediatrician for specific treatment of clubfoot
Obtain written consent from parent or legal caretaker
Modify the examination and treatment as indicated for patients with coexisting conditions such as muscular dystrophy, cerebral palsy, or meningomyelocele
Secure parental involvement and commitment to the treatment plan and daily protocol
Provide a calm and quiet environment to lessen patient anxiety
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Notify physician immediately if no sensation or motor response is found in the affected foot
Postpone examination of patients with unresolved conditions such as foot infection, unhealed surgical wound, or fracture
Follow physician/surgeon’s orders and postoperative protocol as closely as possible. Noncompliance with bracing in the Ponseti method is associated with relapse(11)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury -Clubfoot is idiopathic in most cases -When was clubfoot diagnosed in the patient? -What is the patient’s current score on the Dimeglio classification system?

course of treatment.medical management: Patients are usually under the general care of a pediatrician and/or a pediatric orthopedist. The Ponseti method of manipulation and serial casting is widely used.(23) Management includes use of orthoses and bracing such as the traditional DenisBrowne  (DB) abduction brace at night to up to 5 years of age(11) In areas around the world where medical resources are not as readily available, clubfoot in children may not be diagnosed until after they have begun walking and develop what is termed “neglected clubfoot.” This causes societal  stigma and can significantly impact quality of life, including the ability to participate in ageappropriate  activities and attend school, as well as employment and marriage in later life(10) If the clubfoot is not corrected by the time the child is of ambulatory age, the effects of weight-bearing  on the affected limb worsen the equinovarus deformities and the foot becomes nonreducible. The lateral column of the foot (calcaneus and cuboid) elongates more than the medial column (talus, navicular, and cuneiform), creating a rigid foot and ankle(10) Severe neglected clubfoot is associated with pain and difficulty with weight-bearing  and ambulation, recurrent skin breakdown with associated infections, and ultimately amputation(8)
surgical management: Surgical management: Was clubfoot repair surgery performed (e.g., posteromedial and lateral soft-tissue  release,
Achilles tenotomy, cuboidosteotomy combined with selective softtissue release)? What was the date of surgery? Describe the procedure. Any postoperative complications to note?
Surgery is usually followed by bracing for about 6 weeks, followed by bracing at night
Factors that may be used to predict increased risk for surgical intervention in patients undergoing treatment for idiopathic clubfoot are the following:(16)
Those patients with higher Dimeglio scores at presentation and at initiation of the brace use
Those patients who are not compliant with brace use
course of treatment.medications: Some children may receive acetaminophen (never aspirin) for pain after surgery
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: Ask about findings on X-rays  or other imaging studies
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Has patient received any alternative treatments (e.g., chiropractic, craniosacral, Rolfing)?
course of treatment.previous therapy: Has the patient received physical therapy previously for lower extremity musculoskeletal conditions and, if so, what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful? What therapy intervention was rendered before, after, or during the medical/surgical management of the clubfoot?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: What factors increase or decrease symptoms? Is there pain upon weight-bearing?  Pain with ROM?
history of present illness.body chart: Use chart of the lower extremity to document location and nature of symptoms, as applicable
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Patient may present with -pain/tenderness -inflammation/swelling -impaired foot mobility -impaired standing balance
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: If applicable, use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment. Specifically address if pain is the primary symptom and whether it is present now and how much. The Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (FLACC) Scale may be used as well(2)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document whether there are changes in symptoms throughout the day and night (i.e., A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Condition usually does not disturb sleep quality
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms that may complicate treatment, such as muscle weakness or poor balance. Do compensatory changes in posture or movements exacerbate the problem? Does the type of shoe or orthotic support change the symptoms? Barriers to learning -Is communication with patient limited by age or language, hearing, vision, or cognitive impairment?

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Is there coexisting movement dysfunction, such as muscular dystrophy or cerebral palsy?
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a complete list of current medications
past medical history.other symptoms: Are there any musculoskeletal problems or functional concerns other than clubfoot?

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: What modifications can be implemented to allow the child to participate in desired activities during the period of rehabilitation?Determine the extent to which symptoms interfere with ADLs or use of adaptive equipmentAre there barriers in the home that impede access, such as stairs? What modifications are needed?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess fit of splint or brace applied after surgical correction, if applicable. Assess need for assistive device in ambulation –Assess compliance with use of splints or braces if applicable -Adherence to orthoses-wearing  protocols is postulated to improve treatment outcomes; however, actual wear rates have been found to be lower than patient (parent)-reported  wear rates(14) -Noncompliance with the use of the foot-ankle  orthosis has been associated with the highest risk for surgical intervention(16)
relevant tests and measures.balance: When appropriate for weight-bearing  status, assess balance in standing and single-leg  stance. Use the Pediatric Balance Scale (PBS) or the balance subtest of the Peabody Developmental Motor Scales, Second Edition (PDMS-2)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess if bilateral pedal pulses are present and symmetrical; assess capillary refill at toe tips
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Functional mobilityDetermine the extent to which symptoms interfere with ADLs or use of adaptive equipment –The PDMS-2  or WeeFIM are standardized tools that can be used
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess ability of nonambulatory patient to crawl, as indicated. In ambulatory child, assess lower extremity and rearfoot alignment and ankle movement in barefooted walking (on treadmill, if appropriate) at heel strike, stance, and push-off –Expect excessive internal rotation of the affected foot –Disturbances in phases of gait prior to surgical correction include -equinus gait  – reduced dorsiflexion during stance -calcaneus gait – reduced plantar flexion at toe-off -foot drop – increased plantar flexion at the end of swing -knee hyperextension  – during midstance –Be aware that gait analysis has shown that children with unilateral clubfoot often alter the gait mechanics of the unaffected side to maintain gait symmetry(17)Assess joint mobility using the Paris Stoddard Scale for mobility, noting any hypomobility or hypermobility of the foot and ankle. Screen young children for hip dysplasia using the Ortolani or Barlow test(11) –For infants, assess hindfoot (talocrural) and midfoot mobility (i.e., pronate and supinate forefoot while holding the heel in neutral position). For older children, assess passive accessory motion at the talocrural, subtalar, tarsometatarsal, and metatarsophalangeal joints
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess bilateral lower extremity muscle strength using manual muscle testing (MMT) in the older patient, paying particular attention to isolating the foot and ankle musculature. For the younger child or infant, observe spontaneous active movement in gravity and antigravity positions, if possible –After correction of idiopathic and nonidiopathic clubfoot using the Ponseti method, only poor evertor muscle strength was associated with recurrence after 2 years(12)
observation inspection palpation includi: Assess for leg-length  discrepancy using supine to sit. Note if true or functional leg-length  discrepancy
Inspect the affected lower extremity for any signs of inflammation (warmth, redness, or swelling)
Assess skin integrity for any signs of skin breakdown. Note location, size, and color of any wound or surgical site. Skin irritation may also be related to the use of a splint or brace
Document the presence of any clubfoot deformity or any other musculoskeletal deformity (e.g., ankle equinus, heel varus, forefoot adduction, midfootcavus)

Palpate for muscle atrophy (very common in the gastrocsoleus and the intrinsic foot muscles) •Pain/tenderness: Assess with age-appropriate  pain scale when palpating the joints and soft tissue structures of the knee, foot, and ankle
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess bilateral lower extremity ROM as well as the great toe and digits. ROM will most likely be decreased at the foot and ankle due to tightness or muscle contractures in the Achilles tendon, tibialis posterior, flexor hallucis longus, and flexor digitorum longus –Less dorsiflexion motion is associated with higher rates of further surgical intervention(18)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess infant for newborn reflexes (e.g., Moro, asymmetrical tonic neck reflex, Babinski). For older children, assess for the integration of these newborn reflexes as well as the patellar and Achilles deep tendon reflexesAssess bilateral lower extremities for any sensory impairments (e.g., light touch, pinprick, joint proprioception). Dermatomal and myotomal testing for bilateral lower extremities is appropriate. Give particular attention to the distribution of the superficial peroneal nerve (dorsum of foot) and deep peroneal nerve (1st web space)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –Dimeglio classification system(1) –Clubfoot Assessment Protocol

contraindications precautions: Infant feedings may assist in calming the child
Patient distraction and relaxation strategies may be employed
Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
Persons with an aversion to cold
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment when choosing to use modalities

Ambulatory patients with clubfoot may be at increased risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention  instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Inform patient and family/caregivers of the potential for falls and educate about fall-prevention  strategies
Adapt therapeutic exercises for ambulatory patients with functional limitations (e.g., poor balance/weight-bearing  status, poor coordination)
Involve parent/caregiver in comforting infant/child patient during treatment sessions

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Early intervention with physical therapy treatment should be recommended. Clubfoot can impact a child’s overall development, especially gross motor skills. Decreased lower extremity and core strength, impaired functional and age-appropriate mobility, decreased static and standing balance, impaired ankle/foot joint mobility, and decreased lower extremity ROM and flexibility can impact the child’s motor development. Parent education regarding the child’s condition, treatment plan, and prognosis is a key component in the child’s rehabilitation
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Metatarsus adductus  Congenital talipes valgus Congenital metatarsus primus varus Claw foot Cavovarus deformity of foot
prognosis: The Ponseti method of management, which is used worldwide, has an excellent correction rate in children ≤ 2 years. It also appears to be effective in neglected clubfoot (i.e., treatment started after child has started walking or after 2 years of age), although the upper age limit has not been determined(23) –Based on a case series in India, 44 of 49 patients (89.8%) treated with the Ponseti method for idiopathic clubfoot were reported to have good to excellent results at mean follow-up of 5 years(4)
Management of both resistant or relapsed clubfoot after conservative treatment and neglected clubfoot usually requires patient-specific surgical treatment (e.g., Achilles tenotomy and/or bracing)(11)

Residual equinus deformity after Ponseti method and Achilles tenotomy was found to be associated with a high rate of future surgical procedures(18) –Based on a study of 148 feet conducted in the United States that examined what factors were predictive of the need for surgical correction. Average dorsiflexion for the group that did not require further surgery was 14 degrees, while the average for the group that did receive further surgery was 5.1 degrees

Authors of a meta-regression  that looked at the reoccurrence rate in Ponseti-treated  clubfeet stated that reoccurrence happens in 7–64% of children with idiopathic clubfeet(24) –Highest rate of reoccurrence was seen in children with unilateral deformity who received tenotomy and were followed up less than 2 years

Two studies looked at the need for surgery by the age of 10 as an outcome measure, comparing the Ponseti technique and the French physical therapy (PT) method (described in Treatment Summary  below) –Gross motor skills were evaluated using the Bruininks-Oseretsky  Test of Motor Proficiency, Second Edition (BOT-2) of 172 patients, comparing initial treatment (Ponseti or PT), initial clubfoot severity (Dimeglio ≤ 13 vs > 13), laterality (unilateral or bilateral), and surgical versus nonoperative outcome (25) -Patients in PT group scored significantly higher on running speed/agility, body coordination, strength, and agility. All other measures were similar between groups -Impaired balance was seen in patients with bilateral involvement and those requiring surgery –Functional outcomes of children at 10 years of age were compared between children who underwent nonoperative treatment only (Ponseti or French PT) and those who required subsequent surgery(26) -Those children who required surgery (posterior release or posteromedial release) had less ankle power and isokinetic strength when compared to children who had nonoperative treatment only -Both nonoperatively and surgically treated clubfeet had significant limitations in plantarflexion ROM, power, and torque when compared to age-matched controls
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthotist/pedorthist for bracing modifications, orthoses, and orthopedic footwear Podiatric orthopedist for surgical consult in cases that require further evaluation/ treatment compared to conservative care Wound care specialist as indicated
other considerations: Although parents of an infant born with clubfoot are often told to seek treatment as soon as possible, clubfoot has been shown to not be an orthopedic emergency: treatment begun later has not been shown to be inferior to treatment that starts immediately(19) –A lower rate of relapse and better clinical outcomes were seen when treatment was initiated between 28 days and 3 months of age(27) -Based on a Chinese study of 90 children (131 feet) with a mean follow-up  of 5 years -Early treatment (< 28 days) was associated with more casts and higher relapse rate
Infants with untreated idiopathic clubfoot have an increased risk of developmental hip dysplasia (11)

Despite the overall high success rates with the Ponseti and French PT methods, a small percentage of children may still present with some residual foot deformities (e.g., supination, metatarsus adductus), even after subsequent casting/splinting or soft tissue release. A custom foot orthotic may be required to accommodate these deformities

Authors of a synthesis of previous research on treatment-seeking factors for clubfoot in middle-  and low-income  countries identified the following barriers to treatment(20) –Intrapersonal barriers: lack of income; additional responsibilities; guardian’s belief regarding cause of clubfoot; support of fathers, extended family, and community –Institutional barriers: long distances to treatment centers, insufficient information about treatments, and challenges following treatments –Public-policy  barriers: two-tiered  healthcare system makes it difficult for some patients to get timely care

Surgical intervention –Residual equinovarus deformity may follow Ponseti treatment and percutaneous Achilles tenotomy for severe clubfoot. Predictive factors found for residual deformity in 50 retrospective cases included Pirani score, lateral tibiocalcaneal angle, and talocalcaneal angle preceding Ponsetitreatment(9) –Cuboid subtraction osteotomy combined with posteromedial release is an effective surgical approach to manage rigid neglected clubfoot deformity(10) -Based on a study conducted in Italy that included 31 patients (56 feet) older than 5 years -Average follow-up  time was 6 years -Using the Laaveg and Ponseti classifications, 24 feet had excellent correction, 20 feet had good correction, 9 had fair correction, and only 3 had poor correction at 1 year postsurgical repair, with results being maintained up to the patient’s last follow-up -Significant improvements in Dimeglio score were observed following surgical repair
treatment summary: The goal is essentially the same for idiopathic and nonidiopathicclubfoot; i.e., to achieve a plantigrade foot, with or without an Achilles tenotomy

There are two well-established  nonoperative treatment approaches –Ponseti nonsurgical or semi-operative  method(5) -Serial manipulation and long-leg  casting; manipulation in Ponseti method described as gentle stretching of soft tissues(6) -Percutaneous Achilles tenotomy, if necessary to achieve plantigrade foot -DB abduction brace for 3 months at night and during naps for patients aged 2 to 3 years –French PT method(7) -Daily 30-minute  sequence of gentle manipulations during the time the baby is relaxed or asleep after having been fed. These manipulations start with gentle joint tractions, then progressive reduction of each deformity. A major requisite is that the baby never cries during the manipulations and splinting for first 8 weeks -Followed by manipulations and splinting, with interim bracing 3 times weekly

Treatment overview–Ponseti  (11) –Initial treatment varies with age -Serial casting to begin within first month of life, although recent research suggests that it should start between 28 days and 3 months of age(27) -Gentle manipulations and stretching with casting are performed weekly until maximum effect achieved at 5 to 8 weeks -Heel cord lengthening surgery once maximum effect, after which placed in long-leg  cast for 3 weeks -Denis-Brown  abduction device can be used at night for 3 to 5 years -Over 18 months – bony surgery if soft tissue surgery failed -Over 4 years – tendon transfers useful, especially if recurrent disease –Useful bony operations include metatarsal osteotomies, calcanealosteotomies, intertarsal fusions

Related research comparing the different methods –The Ponseti method and the French PT method were found to have similar clinical outcomes in a prospective United States cohort study(8) -Two hundred fifty-six  infants with idiopathic clubfoot/clubfeet were assigned to the Ponseti method vs the French physical therapy method based on parental preference -One hundred seventy-six  infants (267 clubfeet) were treated with the Ponseti method -Eighty infants (119 clubfeet) were treated with the French PT method -Outcomes were classified as -Good – plantigrade foot with or without a heel-cord  tenotomy  -Fair – plantigrade foot that had or needed to have a limited posterior release, a tibialis anterior tendon transfer, and/or lateral column shortening -Poor – plantigrade foot that had or needed to have a complete posteromedial surgical release -Mean follow-up  was 4.3 years -Comparing Ponseti method vs the French physical therapy method -Percentage of clubfeet with good outcomes, 72% vs 67% (not significant) -Percentage of clubfeet with fair outcomes, 12% vs 17% (not significant) -Percentage of clubfeet with poor outcomes, 16% vs 16% (not significant) –Gait analysis can provide additional information to assist with determining which nonoperative treatment intervention may be optimal for restoring normalized gait biomechanics –A three-phase  PT program after treatment with the Ponseti method was found to be effective in increasing ROM, functional status, and treatment satisfaction in children with clubfoot(28) -Based on a Turkish study involving 62 patients with unilateral clubfoot -Outcome measures were ROM, one-leg  standing test, sit to stand test, the Oxford Ankle-Foot  Questionnaire for Children and Parent, and treatment satisfaction -The 3-phase  PT program lasted 3 months and consisted of the following: -Phase 1 –rhythmic  and repeated mobilizations to subtalar and talocrural joints, stretching to Achilles and foot invertors and intrinsics, education on home exercise program (plantar fascia relaxation massage, subtalar mobilization, active assistive dorsiflexion and eversion ROM, sensory stimulation to anterior tibialis and peroneus longus) -Phase 2 – continued mobilizations as in phase 1, kinesiology taping for fibularis longus and brevis muscle, functional exercises (ball exercises, weight bearing) -Phase 3 – balance and proprioception training, strengthening exercises for tibialis anterior and peroneal muscles –Comparison of plaster of Paris (POP) and semirigid fiberglass (SRF)cast material revealed no significant difference in the number of casts required to correct clubfoot(13) -Based on an RCT conducted in Canada involving 30 patients -SRF resulted in a more favorable parental experience, particularly with respect to ease of removal –Comparison of POP cast material and semirigid soft cast revealed that the soft cast was superior to the POP cast in the areas of parent satisfaction and cast-related complication rates(21) -Based on an RCT conducted in Turkey involving 196 babies (249 feet) -Similar to the above study, no difference was found in number of castings -.
